Chapter 12, Part 3: The Chapter on the Bodhisattva of Infinite Meaning
At that time, the Bodhisattva of Infinite Meaning said to ÅšÄriputra:
The cultivation of loving-kindness by the bodhisattva is also inexhaustible.
Why is it so?

The loving-kindness of the bodhisattva is immeasurable and boundless. The cultivation of loving-kindness has no fixed limit, but covers the realm of sentient beings. The bodhisattva cultivates loving-kindness and gives rise to the mind to universally cover.
ÅšÄriputra!
Just as space universally covers everything, the loving-kindness of the bodhisattva is also like this, covering all sentient beings without exception.

ÅšÄriputra!ğŸ”½Just as the realm of sentient beings is immeasurable, boundless, and inexhaustible, the cultivation of loving-kindness by the bodhisattva is also like this, immeasurable, boundless, and inexhaustible.

Because space is inexhaustible, sentient beings are inexhaustible. Because sentient beings are inexhaustible, the cultivation of loving-kindness by the bodhisattva is also inexhaustible. This is called the loving-kindness cultivated by the great being, which cannot be exhausted.
ÅšÄriputra said:
Good man!
How much is considered the realm of sentient beings?
Akshayamati said:
The realm of earth, water, fire, and wind is immeasurable and boundless, but it is still not as much as the realm of sentient beings.
ÅšÄriputra said:
Yes, good man!
Can you give a simile?
Akshayamati said:
It can be said, but one cannot use a small matter as a simile.
ÅšÄriputra!

To the east, past a world system consisting of a billion worlds, in the south, west, north, the four intermediate directions, above and below, all a billion worlds away, form a great ocean filled to the brim with water.

Suppose all the sentient beings in a world system consisting of one billion worlds were to gather together and break a single hair into a hundred parts, then use one of these parts to take up a single drop of water from the great ocean, and two world systems were to take up two drops, and so on, until all the water in the great ocean was exhausted, the realm of sentient beings would still not be exhausted;
the bodhisattva's mind of loving-kindness is able to universally cover all these sentient beings.
ÅšÄriputra!
What do you think?
Is the power of the roots of goodness cultivated by this loving-kindness practice exhaustible?
ÅšÄriputra said:
It is truly inexhaustible.
Good man!
The nature of space may still be exhausted, but the bodhisattva's mind of loving-kindness is inexhaustible.
If there are bodhisattvas who, upon hearing this teaching, do not give rise to fear, one should know that these people have attained inexhaustible loving-kindness.

The vehicle of compassion is able to gather non-material merits, and compassion nurtures all merits.
Compassion surpasses all merits of non-action, and compassion is able to adorn the major and minor marks.
Compassion is able to abandon inferior dull faculties, and compassion is able to open the correct path to the good and nirvana for heavenly beings and humans.
Compassion is able to abandon the three evil destinies and the eight difficulties, and compassion loves and delights in all good dharmas.

Compassion is like a wish, accomplishing all that is desired freely. Compassion is impartial towards all sentient beings. Compassion initiates activity, abandoning all different characteristics. Compassion correctly heads towards the gate of upholding precepts.
Compassion is able to protect those who violate precepts. Compassion is able to accomplish the unsurpassed power of patience.
Compassion is able to abandon all arrogance and negligence. Compassion initiates the practice of non-disputation and progresses towards the correct path.
Compassion is the fundamental entry into the holy dhyana concentration. The goodness of compassion is able to discriminate the mind and abandon all.
Afflictions are the cause of kindness. Wisdom gives rise to dhÄraá¹‡Ä«s, languages, and written words, which are the companions of the concentration of kindness.
Free from the companions of MÄra and afflictions, kindness always abides together with joy. Kindness is what the mind
commands with kindness. Kindness firmly upholds the precepts of dignified conduct. Kindness is able to leave behind all agitation and so forth.
Kindness is able to extinguish various kinds of characteristics. The fragrant incense of kindness anoints the body with a sense of shame and dishonor.
Kindness is able to remove the foul smell of afflictions.
ÅšÄriputra!
Those who cultivate kindness are all able to protect all sentient beings and are able to give up their own happiness and bestow it upon other sentient beings.
The kindness cultivated by Å›rÄvakas is limited to their own persons, while the kindness of bodhisattvas extends to all immeasurable sentient beings.

Those who cultivate kindness are able to cross over all flows. Where kindness reaches, there are sentient beings with karmic affinities, and there are also those with no karmic affinities.
Those with karmic affinities are the initial generation of the mind.
Conditioned by dharmas means having already practiced.
Unconditioned by conditions means attaining profound acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas.

This is called the bodhisattva's practice of great loving-kindness being inexhaustible.

ÅšÄriputra!
Just as the life-faculty of a person is based on the in-breath and out-breath, so the bodhisattva's cultivation and learning of the Great Vehicle is based on great compassion.
Just as the wheel-turning sage king is based on the precious wheel, so the bodhisattva's cultivation of omniscience is based on great compassion.
Just as a great elder has only one child and cherishes him with deep love, so the bodhisattva's great compassion is also like this, loving all beings as if they were his own children.

Such great compassion is what I have already practiced, such great compassion is what I have already done for my own benefit, such great compassion does not rely on the affairs of others, such great compassion is what arises from one's own mind without flattery, such great compassion is what arises from the ultimate determination, such great compassion arises from the nature of the lineage, such great compassion arises from the straight path, such great compassion arises from the mind without crookedness and uprightness.

Such great compassion arises from the realm of sentient beings without arrogance, such great compassion arises from the TathÄgata's body by abandoning one's own body, such great compassion arises from not doing evil by not being attached to life, such great compassion arises from bodhi by protecting sentient beings, such great compassion arises from the purity of the mind by protecting the true Dharma, such great compassion arises from the act of rescuing by seeing those in distress, such great compassion arises from the unshakable mind by the firmness of one's original vow, such great compassion arises from not deceiving oneself, humans, gods, and sages by not being deceitful.

Such great compassion arises from pure conduct and good deeds. Such great compassion arises from giving one's own happiness to others. Such great compassion arises from not causing harm to others. Such great compassion arises from the power of patience and protection of the weak. Such great compassion arises from not being disgusted by the sick. Such great compassion arises from attaining mastery over the Dharma and teaching those with dull faculties. Such great compassion arises from concealing one's own virtues and revealing the virtues of others. Such great compassion arises from transcending all suffering. Such great compassion arises from seeking the undefiled bliss.
Such great compassion arises from giving away beloved possessions. Such great compassion arises from creating various good deeds
without causing harm. Such great compassion arises from well-guarding the precepts and not abandoning those who violate the precepts. Such
great compassion arises from teaching and transforming sentient beings. Such great compassion arises from not cherishing one's body and life. Such
Great compassion arises from abandoning one's own limbs and joints. Such great compassion gives rise to others' wholesome roots.
Such great compassion arises from one's own wholesome roots. Such great compassion arises from the flavorless dhyÄnas.
Such great compassion arises from not being disgusted with the desire realm. Such great compassion arises from insight.
Such great compassion arises from not defiling wholesome roots. Such great compassion arises from accomplishing the wishes of all beings.
Such great compassion arises from the conditioned and the unconditioned. Such great compassion arises from not realizing the unconditioned.
Such great compassion arises from knowing the nature of beings is the same as the unconditioned yet being able to teach and transform. Such

great compassion arises from the great compassion of the MahÄyÄna. For these causes and conditions, it is called great compassion.

Those with great compassion will definitely skillfully practice giving, upholding precepts, patience, diligence, meditation, and wisdom, the various auxiliary practices of the path, in order to attain the wisdom of no-teacher-dependence. They will engage in the activities of other sentient beings with diligence and focus, just as if they were doing their own work. For these reasons, they are called those with great compassion.
ÅšÄriputra!
This is called the bodhisattvas' practice of great compassion, which is inexhaustible.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas' practice of joy is also inexhaustible.
What is joy?

Constantly contemplating the Dharma, rejoicing and leaping with joy, not giving rise to laziness, being free from all afflictions and heat, leaving behind the pleasures of the five desires and abiding in the pleasure of the Dharma, with a mind of harmony and delight, a body that is light and pliable, a mind that diligently encourages and guides, and a heart that always gives rise to compassion, joyfully seeking the TathÄgata's unsurpassed Dharma body.

They delight in cultivating the major and minor marks to adorn themselves, listen to the Dharma without weariness, contemplate practicing the true Dharma, and after practicing the true Dharma, give rise to a joyful mind. Having given rise to joy, they fully attain the compassion of the Dharma.

They always give rise to an unobstructed mind towards sentient beings, and with superior desire diligently seek the Dharma. Having diligently desired the Dharma, they deeply attain understanding of the profound Buddha Dharma, and far remove themselves from the Two Vehicles, giving rise to the unsurpassed mind. They eliminate all stinginess and give rise to the mind of abandonment. Seeing those who come to beg, they give rise to a joyful mind. At the time of giving, they are joyful, and after giving, they have no regrets. Thus, their giving is pure in the three periods of time. Having attained purity, their minds are then delighted. They always practice giving to those who uphold the precepts, and with a joyful mind, they accept those who violate the precepts.
They themselves uphold the precepts, and their minds are then pure.

They are able to cause sentient beings who are frightened by the evil paths to attain fearlessness and to distance themselves from evil places. With a one-pointed mind, they aspire towards the TathÄgata's precepts, upholding them firmly and unwaveringly. If scolded or cursed, they are able to endure it without retaliation.
One should be free from arrogance towards sentient beings, humble and respectful towards elders, and always speak pleasantly, free from frowns.
One should always speak affectionately, without flattery, not deceive others with a false mind, not serve others for the sake of material gain, and have a pure mind without coarse faults.

One should not see faults in the unacceptable, not seek the shortcomings of others, not bring up the faults of others, and single-mindedly contemplate the harmonious and respectful teachings, giving rise to the thought of the TathÄgata towards all bodhisattvas.
One should cherish those who expound the Dharma more than one's own body, and cherish the TathÄgata as one would one's own life.

One should give rise to the thought of parents towards teachers and elders, the thought of children towards all sentient beings, protect the various dignified deportments as one would one's head, cherish the various perfections as one would one's hands and feet, give rise to the thought of precious treasures towards all wholesome dharmas, give rise to the thought of the five desires towards those who instruct and admonish, give rise to the thought of being free from illness towards the practice of contentment, and give rise to the thought of wonderful medicine towards the delight in seeking the Dharma.
One should give rise to the thought of a good doctor towards the one who brings up faults, and control the senses without laziness. Therefore, it is called joy.
This joy is tranquil because it is aware of the subtle, this joy is extinguished because it is without arrogance or playfulness,
this joy is dependent on practice because it is without idle speculation, this joy is the fundamental basis because the mind is not disturbed, this joy
is due to much learning because one takes up good speech, this joy is equanimous because the mind is pliant, this joy is
courageous because one skillfully performs good actions, this joy is without regret because one exclusively practices good, this joy is rightly abiding because one is not lazy,
this joy is unmoving because it is without dependence, this joy is not shared because it is difficult to subdue,
this joy is the true meaning because it is not forgotten, this joy is true reality because it is without change, this joy

is sincere because it is as it is done, this joy is able to let go because its power is firm, this joy is of great power because it is invincible, this joy is able to perform the spiritual powers of the buddhas because it seeks the buddhadharmas.
ÅšÄriputra!
This is called the bodhisattvas' practice of joy, which is inexhaustible.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas' practice of equanimity is also inexhaustible.
How is it that the bodhisattvas' practice of equanimity is inexhaustible?
The bodhisattvas' practice of equanimity has three kinds.
What are the three?
Abandoning all afflictions, abandoning protection of self and others, abandoning timely and untimely [actions].
What is abandoning all afflictions?
With a respectful and reverent mind, one does not become arrogant; with a humble and respectful mind, one does not become discouraged.
If one obtains material gain, one's mind does not become greedy or conceited; if one encounters misfortune and distress, one's mind does not become sorrowful.
If one encounters praise and acclaim, one's mind does not become joyful; if one encounters slander and criticism, one's mind does not become discouraged.
If one encounters ridicule and mockery, one's mind does not become deflated; if one encounters praise and acclaim, one abides well in the dharma realm.
If one encounters painful events, one's mind has the strength to endure them; if one encounters pleasant events, one clearly sees their impermanence.

Giving up what is cherished and cutting off anger, attaining an impartial mind towards relatives and strangers, having no increase or decrease in attitude towards those who uphold precepts and those who violate precepts, having no two appearances for good and evil deeds.

The mind is unattached to what is loved and what is not loved, the mind is able to endure what is heard as good or bad, the mind is not attached to good or evil words, the measure of faults in flavors is no different.

Attaining an impartial mind towards all beings, attaining equal light towards the superior, middling, and inferior, not sparing one's life, and regarding good and bad fame as the same as the Dharma realm.
The mind attains purity towards real and unreal dharmas, and attains the bodhisattva's abandonment towards worldly dharmas and so forth. This is called the bodhisattva's abandonment of afflictions.
How does the bodhisattva abandon protecting oneself and others?

If one's body and limbs are cut off, the mind has no anger or resentment and does not seek revenge, because one attains the mind of abandonment one is able to abandon the two, the inner and outer body and speech, and does not give rise to disputes within these two.

There is no defilement in the eyes and forms, and the same is so for the ears and sounds, nose and smells, tongue and tastes, body and tactile objects, and mind and dharmas. Therefore, not giving rise to disputes between the two is called equanimity.
Not injuring or harming is therefore called equanimity, and abandoning self-protection is therefore called equanimity.

Equally practicing the mind towards benefit and non-benefit is therefore called equanimity. Not giving rise to disputes in the ultimate truth is therefore called equanimity, and well being able to discriminate in one's own mind is therefore called equanimity.
Observing the abandonment of one's own body is therefore called equanimity, and not harming others' bodies is therefore called equanimity.

Bodhisattvas cultivate equanimity and always practice the mind of equanimity in all dhyÄna concentrations. The buddhas, the world-honored ones, do not allow bodhisattvas to practice the mind of equanimity towards sentient beings.
Why is it so?
Bodhisattvas always cultivate diligence to benefit themselves and others and diligently seek wholesome roots. This is called the bodhisattvas' abandonment of self-protection.
What is the time and non-time for abandonment?

Not accepting or guiding sentient beings who are not suitable vessels, and not accepting slander, humiliation, criticism, or suffering. Abandoning those who seek to become Å›rÄvakas who have reached certainty.

When practicing giving, abandoning cultivation of precepts; when cultivating precepts, abandoning giving; when cultivating patience, abandoning giving, precepts, and vigor; when cultivating vigor, abandoning giving, precepts, and patience; when practicing meditation, abandoning giving; when cultivating wisdom, abandoning the five perfections. What should not be done is never done again.
Thus, these dharmas abide in the practice of precepts, diligently and courageously perfecting practice. This is called the bodhisattva's cultivation of inexhaustible giving.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
The various supernormal powers of the bodhisattva are also inexhaustible.
What are the various supernormal powers?

The supernormal power of the divine eye, the supernormal power of the divine ear, the supernormal power of knowing others' minds, the supernormal power of recollecting past lives, and the supernormal power of mental powers.
What is the supernormal power of the divine eye?

The divine eye of the bodhisattvas is the foremost and most excellent among the divine eyes of all devas, nÄgas, gandharvas, learners, post-learners, Å›rÄvakas, and pratyekabuddhas, being subtle, superior, open, clear, and directed towards omniscience, accomplished through merit, and not shared by devas, nÄgas, or the two vehicles.

If there are the appearances, forms, colors, and light of all buddha-realms in the boundless and limitless worlds of the ten directions, whether coarse or fine, near or far, the divine eye of the bodhisattvas sees them all, illuminating and discerning them well, and also sees the sentient beings therein who are born in the various destinies, except for the formless devas.
The remaining karmic actions and the continuity of birth and death, as well as the karmic fruits and the discernment of all faculties, are all known without exception.

If one sees without exception all the pure and wondrous lands adorned by the innumerable and boundless buddhas of the ten directions, having seen thus, one should maintain pure precepts and vow to dedicate them to the adornment of one's own land.
Abiding in these precepts, as one wishes, one will accomplish immeasurable great benefits.

because its nature is clear. This eye is not dependent because it is free from objects. This eye does not arise because it cuts off afflictions.

This great being abides in great compassion and deeply understands the characteristics of dharmas. He skillfully distinguishes the meaning without dispute, and speaks according to what he sees and hears. He turns his back on unwholesome dharmas and heads towards the place of enlightenment, with a mind free from obstructions.

Seeing stingy people, they are able to give up their wealth and practice generosity; seeing those who violate precepts, they cultivate and uphold pure precepts; seeing the angry, they cultivate patience and do not quarrel; seeing the lazy, they gather and encourage them; seeing the scattered-minded, they demonstrate the branches of meditation; those without wisdom, they bestow the eye of wisdom; those who follow wrong paths, they show the right path; for those who practice inferior ways, they explain the profound and subtle Buddha Dharma, causing them to enter omniscience and not regress from the spiritual powers, fully perfecting enlightenment.

This bodhisattva's divine ear also knows holy sounds and non-holy sounds.
When hearing holy sounds, he does not give rise to attachment, and when hearing non-holy sounds, his mind does not become obstructed.
With regard to the sounds of holy beings, he attains great kindness, and with regard to the sounds of non-holy beings, he attains great compassion.
If he hears the various sounds of the past and future, he attains the perfect wisdom that exhausts the ultimate point.

This bodhisattva's heavenly ear can hear all the wonderful teachings spoken by the buddhas of the ten directions. Having heard them, he remembers them with right wisdom and total retention, without forgetting or losing them. He teaches the Dharma according to the capacities of sentient beings and well understands the characteristics of the firmness and unfirmness of all dharmas.
It is impossible for this bodhisattva to hear the Dharma taught by one buddha without hearing the Dharma taught by other buddhas.
He is able to listen to and accept all the teachings expounded by the buddhas. If the bodhisattva hears good, bad, or neutral sounds, he knows well whether it is the right time or not.
Namely, if there are sentient beings but it is not the time to teach the Dharma, he hears and remains silent without speaking.
If it is the time to teach but there are no sentient beings, namely if there is only one person who is able to receive it, he therefore teaches even though it is not for everyone.
If the matter is true but he fears it will hurt others, he does not speak. If the matter is false but it benefits others, he speaks skillfully with a pure mind.
If it is a sound that is liked, then it can be heard. If it is not liked, then it is not heard.
When expounding the Dharma for sentient beings in the great assembly, according to what is understood and received by the ear consciousness, the bodhisattva's divine ear can hear and know all of it.
When expounding the Dharma, if there are sentient beings who should understand and awaken, then they can hear the Dharma. If they do not understand and awaken, then they do not hear it.
The bodhisattva's ear realm and Dharma realm are by nature pure, because knowing and seeing the self, person, and sentient beings are all pure.
The bodhisattva correctly discerns the ear realm, just as it is described by language and written characters.

If there are sentient beings of the five destinies and various kinds, according to their understanding and the sounds of language, the Dharma is expounded for them. Upholding this divine ear, one aspires to the ear realm attained by the TathÄgata, because one does not seek other vehicles.

Speech is to speak of patience in cutting off anger, resentment, arrogance, and pride. Meaning is to penetrate all dharmas and attain the patience of non-arising.
Speech refers to speaking about diligently practicing all wholesome roots. Meaning refers to abiding in diligence without beginning or end.
Speech refers to speaking about the various meditative absorptions, liberations, concentrations, and samÄdhis. Meaning refers to knowing the concentration of cessation.
Speech refers to being able to hear and retain all written words and the fundamental wisdom. Meaning refers to knowing that the meaning of wisdom cannot be expressed in words.

Speech refers to speaking about the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment. Meaning refers to correctly knowing and practicing the various factors of enlightenment and being able to realize the fruits.
Speech refers to speaking about the truths of suffering, accumulation, and the path. Meaning refers to realizing the truth of cessation.

Speech refers to speaking about the fundamental ignorance up to the conditions leading to birth and old age and death. Meaning refers to knowing the cessation of ignorance up to the cessation of old age and death.
Speech refers to speaking about the methods that assist in concentration and wisdom. Meaning refers to the wisdom of liberation.
Speech refers to speaking about greed, anger, and delusion. Meaning refers to understanding that the roots of non-goodness are themselves liberation.
Speech refers to speaking about obstructive dharmas. Meaning refers to attaining unobstructed liberation.

What is meant by relying on wisdom and not relying on consciousness?
Consciousness refers to the four abodes of consciousness.
What are the four?
The abode of consciousness in form, the abode of consciousness in feelings, conceptions, and volitional predispositions;
Wisdom refers to thoroughly understanding that the nature of the four consciousnesses is without abode.
Consciousness refers to being conscious of the great elements of earth, water, fire, and wind;
Wisdom refers to being conscious that the nature of the four great elements and dharmas is no different.
Consciousness refers to the eye consciousness abiding in form, and the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind consciousnesses abiding in dharmas;
The wise one, with an inner nature of quiescence, does not engage in external activities, and understands that all dharmas are without memory or thought.
Consciousness is exclusively grasping at objects and conceptualizing;
Wisdom is the mind without objects, not grasping at appearances, and having no hopes or desires regarding dharmas.
Consciousness engages in conditioned dharmas;
Wisdom knows unconditioned dharmas, and consciousness has no engagement. The nature of unconditioned dharmas is without consciousness or knowledge.
Consciousness is the characteristic of arising, abiding, and ceasing;
Wisdom is without the characteristics of arising, abiding, and ceasing.

This is called relying on wisdom and not relying on consciousness.

How does one rely on the Dharma and not rely on the person?
The person refers to grasping the view of self, the doer and experiencer.
The Dharma refers to understanding the absence of the view of self, the doer and experiencer.

The person refers to ordinary beings, good people, people of faith and practice, people of Dharma practice, the eight kinds of people, stream-enterers, once-returners, non-returners, arhats, pratyekabuddhas, and bodhisattvas. When a single person appears in the world, it benefits many people, brings happiness to many people, has compassion for the world, and gives rise to a mind of great compassion, bringing much benefit to humans and gods. This refers to the Buddha, the World-Honored One.
The Buddha, relying on worldly truth, spoke in this way in order to transform sentient beings.
If there are those who grasp such views, they are called those who rely on the person.
